questions.text: Implantation occurs how many days after ovulation:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Implantation, the process where a fertilized egg (blastocyst) attaches to the uterine lining, typically occurs 6 days after ovulation. This time frame aligns with the journey of the fertilized egg through the fallopian tube into the uterus, a process that takes about 5-6 days. By this time, the blastocyst has developed sufficiently to embed itself into the uterine wall, where it establishes a connection with the mother’s blood supply to initiate pregnancy. This timeline is supported by clinical evidence and is crucial for the success of early pregnancy. Morula: A solid ball of cells (16-32 cells), formed by cleavage divisions in the early embryo, before the formation of the blastocyst. • Blastocyst: A more advanced stage with a fluid-filled cavity, where cell differentiation occurs, and it is ready for implantation in the uterus. The inner cell mass will form the fetus, and the trophoblast will form the placenta.

questions.text: Trophoblast forms which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The trophoblast, a specialized outer layer of cells in the blastocyst, plays a critical role in the development of the placenta. It specifically forms the chorion, which is one of the extraembryonic membranes. The chorion surrounds the embryo and participates in the formation of the placenta, facilitating the exchange of nutrients, gases, and waste between the mother and the developing fetus. The trophoblast differentiates into two layers: the cytotrophoblast (inner layer) and syncytiotrophoblast (outer layer), which help anchor the embryo to the uterine wall and establish maternal-fetal circulation. Thus, the trophoblast’s primary function is closely associated with the formation of the chorion and its role in supporting pregnancy. Why the other options are incorrect: B) Amnion The amnion is formed from the inner cell mass (embryoblast), not the trophoblast. It is a thin, protective membrane that encloses the amniotic fluid and the developing embryo, providing cushioning and protection. Since the amnion arises from the embryoblast, the trophoblast does not contribute to its formation. C) Yolk Sac The yolk sac is also derived from the inner cell mass and is one of the first structures to form during development. It plays a role in early blood cell production and nutrient transfer before the placenta is fully functional. The trophoblast does not contribute to the formation of the yolk sac. D) Fetus The fetus is formed from the embryoblast, which develops into the epiblast and hypoblast, and eventually differentiates into all the tissues and organs of the body. The trophoblast supports fetal development by forming the placenta but does not directly form the fetus.

Correct Answer: (D) 2 arteries and left umbilical vein The umbilical cord typically contains two arteries and one vein. The two umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood and waste products from the fetus to the placenta, while the single umbilical vein (usually the left umbilical vein) carries oxygenated blood and nutrients from the placenta to the fetus. The right umbilical vein degenerates early in development, leaving the left umbilical vein as the sole functional vein. This structure is essential for maintaining the fetal-maternal exchange of gases, nutrients, and waste during pregnancy. 1. The umbilical cord is made up of three blood vessels: • Two arteries carry deoxygenated blood and waste products from the fetus to the placenta. • One vein carries oxygenated blood and nutrients from the placenta to the fetus. 2. The typical umbilical cord is around 50-60 cm long and about 2 cm in diameter. It is covered by a protective substance called Wharton’s jelly, which provides cushioning and prevents the cord from being compressed or tangled. The umbilical arteries and umbilical vein have low vascular resistance to allow for the efficient flow of blood between the placenta and the fetus. The low-resistance nature of the umbilical vessels can be assessed using Doppler ultrasound. In normal pregnancy, the umbilical artery shows a low-resistance waveform with continuous flow throughout the cardiac cycle. High resistance in the umbilical arteries, seen through Doppler, can indicate potential problems such as placental insufficiency or fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: Interstitial implantation complete by what time :
questions.solution: Correct Answer: (A) 11 days Interstitial implantation refers to the process where the blastocyst completely embeds itself within the endometrium (the uterine lining). This process is typically completed by 11 days after fertilization. By this time, the syncytiotrophoblast, the outer layer of the trophoblast, invades the endometrial tissue, and the blastocyst becomes fully embedded. This stage is crucial for the establishment of maternal-fetal communication and the subsequent development of the placenta. The complete embedding ensures proper nutritional and hormonal support required for the early stages of pregnancy. Most common site of implantation is upper posterior wall. The implantation window is the limited period during the menstrual cycle when the endometrium is receptive to the blastocyst and allows successful implantation. • Typically occurs 6-10 days after ovulation (days 20-24 of a 28-day cycle). • This corresponds to the mid-secretory phase of the menstrual cycle, following progesterone priming of the endometrium. • Key Features of a Receptive Endometrium: • Pinopodes (Uterodomes): Small projections on the luminal surface of the endometrium that aid in blastocyst attachment. • Hormonal Priming: • Progesterone: Secreted by the corpus luteum, prepares the endometrium by stimulating stromal cell differentiation and secretion of supportive molecules. • Estrogen: Modulates progesterone effects and ensures endometrial growth during the follicular phase. • Expression of Adhesion Molecules: • Integrins, selectins, and cadherins facilitate blastocyst attachment. * ?• Secretion of Growth Factors and Cytokines: • Leukemia inhibitory factor (LIF), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), and transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-?) support implantation. The maternal immune system must tolerate the semi-allogeneic embryo. • Uterine Natural Killer (uNK) Cells: Promote trophoblast invasion and vascular remodeling. • Regulatory T cells (Tregs): Suppress maternal immune responses to prevent rejection of the embryo. • HLA-G Expression: Protects trophoblast cells from immune attack by modulating NK cell activity. Vascular Remodeling • Spiral arteries in the uterus are remodeled to provide adequate blood supply. • Mediated by trophoblast cells and uNK cells. • Ensures low-resistance, high-flow blood supply to the developing placenta.

questions.text: After reaching the uterine cavity, a fertilized ovum takes how long to implant itself
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 48 hrs After reaching the uterine cavity, the fertilized ovum (blastocyst) typically takes 48 hours to begin the process of implantation. This time is necessary for the blastocyst to interact with the uterine lining and undergo critical preparatory steps, such as the process of “apposition” (initial contact with the uterine wall) and “adhesion” (attachment to the endometrium). During this period, the uterine lining, under the influence of hormones like progesterone, becomes receptive to implantation. The 48-hour period ensures proper synchronization between the developing embryo and the endometrial environment. Progesterone transforms the endometrial stromal cells into decidual cells, a process called decidualization. Decidua Basalis Found beneath the implanting blastocyst, between the embryo and the myometrium. It directly interacts with the trophoblast to form the maternal portion of the placenta. Provides structural and nutritional support to the developing fetus. Decidua Capsularis Surrounds the blastocyst and separates it from the rest of the uterine cavity. Encases the developing embryo during early pregnancy. Initially thick, but as the fetus grows, it becomes thin and eventually fuses with the decidua parietalis (around 16 weeks) Decidua Parietalis Lines the remainder of the uterine cavity, away from the site of implantation. After implantation, progesterone continues to support pregnancy by: • Preventing uterine contractions. • Maintaining the endometrial lining to prevent menstruation. Progesterone enhances the invasion of trophoblast cells into the endometrium, which is essential for forming the placenta and establishing uteroplacental circulation. Progesterone helps the maternal immune system tolerate the semi-allogeneic embryo: • Promotes the activity of regulatory T cells (Tregs) to suppress maternal immune rejection. • Reduces inflammatory responses by regulating the balance of cytokines (shifts from pro-inflammatory to anti-inflammatory cytokines).

Correct Answer (B) 5 days after fertilisation Zona hatching is the process by which the blastocyst breaks free from the zona pellucida, the protective glycoprotein layer surrounding the fertilized egg. This occurs approximately 5 days after fertilization, allowing the blastocyst to grow in size and prepare for implantation into the uterine lining. The hatching process is essential because the zona pellucida prevents the blastocyst from adhering to inappropriate surfaces before reaching the uterus. Once the blastocyst hatches, it can interact directly with the uterine environment, which is crucial for successful implantation. Functions of Zona Pellucida The zona pellucida (ZP) is a glycoprotein-rich extracellular matrix surrounding the oocyte and early embryo. It has several critical functions: 1. Sperm Binding and Recognition: • The ZP contains specific glycoproteins (e.g., ZP3) that serve as receptors for sperm, facilitating species-specific sperm binding. 2. Induction of the Acrosomal Reaction: • Interaction between the sperm and ZP triggers the acrosomal reaction, allowing the sperm to penetrate the zona pellucida. 3. Prevention of Polyspermy: • Once a sperm fertilizes the oocyte, the ZP undergoes structural modifications (zona reaction) to prevent additional sperm from binding. 4. Protection of the Embryo: • The ZP protects the oocyte and early embryo from physical damage and immune attack as it travels through the reproductive tract. 5. Facilitation of Embryo Transport: • The ZP maintains the structural integrity of the embryo during cleavage and ensures its passage through the fallopian tube. 6. Prevention of Premature Implantation: • The ZP prevents the embryo from attaching to the fallopian tube walls, ensuring implantation occurs only in the uterus. Steps of Fertilization Fertilization is a complex process that involves several sequential steps. Summary Table of Steps

questions.text: Time taken for the capacitation of sperms is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 6-8 hrs Capacitation is the physiological process that sperm undergo in the female reproductive tract to acquire the ability to fertilize an egg. This process typically takes 6-8 hours and involves biochemical and structural changes, such as the removal of glycoproteins and cholesterol from the sperm’s surface. These changes increase the sperm’s motility and prepare it for the acrosomal reaction, which is essential for penetrating the egg’s protective layers. Capacitation is a crucial step that ensures successful fertilization. key points about capacitation: 1. Location: Capacitation occurs in the female reproductive tract, primarily in the fallopian tubes. 2. Biochemical Changes: During capacitation, sperm undergo changes in their membrane structure, including the removal of certain glycoproteins and cholesterol. These changes increase membrane fluidity, allowing for easier interaction with the oocyte. 3. Hyperactivation: Capacitated sperm exhibit hyperactivation, a motility change where the sperm move with increased velocity and exhibit more vigorous, asymmetrical tail beats. This helps them swim through the cervical mucus and towards the egg. 4. Acrosomal Reaction: Capacitation prepares the sperm for the acrosomal reaction, where enzymes are released from the acrosome (a cap-like structure on the sperm’s head). These enzymes are essential for breaking down the zona pellucida, the outer layer of the egg, allowing the sperm to penetrate the egg for fertilization

questions.text: Sperms attain maturity and motility in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Caudal end of epididymis Sperms attain maturity and motility in the caudal end of the epididymis, which is the lower portion of this tightly coiled duct. The epididymis is the site where sperms undergo biochemical and structural changes over a period of 2-3 weeks after being produced in the testes. In the caudal region, sperms gain the ability to swim (motility) and acquire fertilizing capacity, making this region critical for their functional maturation. The caudal end also acts as a storage site for mature sperm until ejaculation. Why the other options are incorrect: A) Cranial end of epididymis The cranial end (head) of the epididymis primarily serves as the entry point for immature sperm from the testes. While some initial biochemical changes begin here, sperm are still immotile and immature at this stage, making this option incorrect. C) Vas deferens The vas deferens is a transport duct that carries mature sperm from the epididymis to the ejaculatory duct. It does not contribute to sperm maturation or motility development, as these processes are completed in the caudal epididymis before the sperm enter the vas deferens. D) Ejaculatory duct The ejaculatory duct is involved in the mixing of sperm with seminal fluid but does not play a role in sperm maturation or motility acquisition. By the time sperm reach this duct, they are already mature and motile, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Which zona pellucida glycoprotein is involved in sperm binding and is altered during the slow block?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ZP3 ZP3 (Zona Pellucida Glycoprotein 3) is the key glycoprotein in the zona pellucida responsible for binding to sperm during fertilization. It serves as the primary sperm receptor and initiates the acrosome reaction, a crucial step in sperm penetration of the oocyte. After the first sperm binds and fuses with the oocyte membrane, cortical granules are released in a process known as the slow block to polyspermy. This reaction alters ZP3 (and ZP2), modifying their structure and preventing further sperm from binding, thereby ensuring that only one sperm fertilizes the egg. This block is vital to prevent polyspermy, which can result in non-viable embryos.

choices.text: They modify zona pellucida proteins to prevent further sperm binding
They attract additional sperm for fertilization

questions.text: What is the function of cortical granules in the slow block to polyspermy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) They modify zona pellucida proteins to prevent further sperm binding Cortical granules play a critical role in the slow block to polyspermy, a mechanism that ensures only one sperm fertilizes the egg. After the first sperm successfully fuses with the oocyte membrane, cortical granules located just beneath the egg membrane release their contents into the perivitelline space. This process is called cortical reaction. The enzymes released from the granules chemically alter the structure of the zona pellucida glycoproteins—particularly ZP2 and ZP3—making them incapable of binding additional sperm. This biochemical modification hardens the zona pellucida and prevents further sperm from penetrating, thus safeguarding against polyspermy, which would otherwise lead to chromosomal abnormalities and non-viable embryos.

questions.text: Capacitation is necessary for sperm to undergo which reaction?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acrosome reaction Capacitation is a physiological process that sperm must undergo after entering the female reproductive tract to become capable of fertilizing an oocyte. This process involves biochemical and structural changes, such as the removal of glycoproteins and cholesterol from the sperm membrane, which increases its permeability to calcium ions and enhances motility. These changes prime the sperm for the acrosome reaction, which is essential for penetrating the zona pellucida of the egg. During the acrosome reaction, enzymes are released from the acrosomal vesicle at the tip of the sperm, allowing it to digest a path through the zona and reach the oocyte membrane for fertilization. Without capacitation, sperm cannot initiate the acrosome reaction, and fertilization cannot occur.

questions.text: The second meiotic division in oogenesis is completed after
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fertilization The second meiotic division in oogenesis is completed only after fertilization. During female gametogenesis, the primary oocyte begins meiosis I during fetal life but is arrested in prophase I until puberty. Upon ovulation, the secondary oocyte is released and starts meiosis II but halts in metaphase II. This secondary oocyte remains arrested in metaphase II until a sperm penetrates it during fertilization. Only then is meiosis II completed, resulting in the formation of a mature ovum and a second polar body. This tightly regulated sequence ensures that the oocyte completes meiosis only when fertilization is imminent, preventing unnecessary energy expenditure and chromosomal errors.

questions.text: Which cell type in the blastocyst is responsible for invading the endometrium?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Trophoblast The trophoblast is the cell layer in the blastocyst responsible for invading the endometrium during implantation. It forms the outer layer of the blastocyst and is the first point of contact with the maternal uterine lining. Upon implantation, the trophoblast differentiates into two layers: the cytotrophoblast (inner layer) and the syncytiotrophoblast (outer layer). The syncytiotrophoblast plays a key role in actively invading the endometrial tissue, facilitating the embedding of the blastocyst into the uterine wall. It also initiates the formation of the placenta and secretes human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which supports early pregnancy by maintaining the corpus luteum.

questions.text: The process by which the blastocyst adheres to the endometrial lining is called
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Apposition Apposition is the initial step in the implantation process where the blastocyst comes into close contact with the endometrial lining of the uterus. This occurs after the blastocyst has traveled through the fallopian tube and reached the uterine cavity. During apposition, the outer trophoblast layer of the blastocyst aligns loosely with the endometrial epithelium, typically at a location in the posterior wall of the uterus. This phase ensures proper orientation for subsequent adhesion and invasion. Apposition is a non-invasive and transient phase, setting the stage for stable attachment and eventual embedding of the blastocyst into the endometrium.

questions.text: Which part of the decidua directly interacts with the chorionic villi to form the maternal part of the placenta?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decidua basalis The decidua basalis is the part of the endometrial lining that lies directly beneath the implanted blastocyst and interacts with the chorionic villi to form the maternal part of the placenta. It plays a critical role in anchoring the placenta and facilitating the exchange of nutrients, gases, and waste between the maternal and fetal circulations. The chorionic villi, which arise from the fetal trophoblast, invade the decidua basalis to establish this connection. Over time, the decidua basalis becomes an essential structural and functional component of the mature placenta, supporting the developing fetus throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: Which hormone primarily prevents superfetation in humans?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Progesterone Progesterone is the primary hormone responsible for preventing superfetation in humans. Superfetation refers to the rare phenomenon where a second ovum is fertilized and implanted during an ongoing pregnancy. In normal human physiology, after fertilization and implantation, progesterone levels rise significantly—first due to the corpus luteum and later from the placenta. This elevated progesterone exerts negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, suppressing the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), and consequently inhibiting FSH and LH. As a result, ovulation is halted during pregnancy, and the endometrium remains in a receptive state to support the existing embryo, effectively preventing additional ovulations and thus superfetation.

questions.text: Superfecundation can only occur in which type of twins?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dizygotic Twins Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two separate ova by sperm from separate acts of intercourse, which may occur within the same ovulatory cycle. This phenomenon can only result in dizygotic (fraternal) twins, as it involves two distinct eggs and two separate sperm. Dizygotic twins are genetically unique, just like any two siblings born at different times, and they may even have different fathers in rare cases (a phenomenon known as heteropaternal superfecundation). Since monozygotic twins arise from a single fertilized egg that later splits, superfecundation is not possible in those cases. The key to superfecundation lies in the presence of multiple eggs released and fertilized during the same cycle, a hallmark of dizygotic twinning
